channel.title: Aftermath's help thread
channel.description:
That's right, I'm going to start giving a damn about you people. Post your questions here, I'll answer them as soon as I feel the need. Go on, do it.
By the way, read this sticky. This is what not to ask. http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,59918.0.html
Read this too. Pre-answered questions. http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,56932.0.html
Those are the questions that I'm not going to bother to answer. Look through that before you ask here, because you'll find the answers there.

item.title: Aftermath's help thread
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Lets make a brand new timer - don’t use actionTimer.

Firstly, declare this:

public int plantTimer = 0;

Then search for boolean process() {
Under that line, put:

if(plantTimer > 0) { plantTimer -= 1; }

That will take 1 away from the value of plantTimer every half a second - so it minuses 2 from the value of plantTimer each second.
Work from there on your own.

Read full topic

Read full topic

item.title: Aftermath's help thread
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Du Thelduin:

Okay, you prolly dunno anything about this (as you probably don’t have the same router as me), but I’m having troubles with my router. It’s not major, but I just don’t know where to put ANYTHING since it is different than all the other help tuts about routers.

Ok, go to start, and select run. In run, type ‘cmd’, without the ’ (quotation marks). Once the command prompt window comes up, type ‘ipconfig’, once again, don’t include the ’ quotation marks.

Once you type that, it will come up with something that looks like this:

Windows IP Configuration
Ethernet adapter Local Area Connection:
Connection-specific DNS Suffix:
IP Address… :192.168.1.10
Subnet Mask… :255.255.255.0
Default Gateway… :192.168.1.1

Now when it comes up with that, you need the number that appears next to Default Gateway - That is the internal IP address of your router. Once you get that number, open either Firefox or Internet Explorer, and put it in the address bar - then hit enter.

From there, you should be in your router’s configuration area. Grab your router’s manual and go from there.

Read full topic

item.title: Aftermath's help thread
item.dc:creator: @Phonecheck Phonecheck
item.description:
@Phonecheck wrote:

[quote=“lothy, post:14, topic:46399”][quote author=Phonecheck link=topic=64594.msg759094#msg759094 date=1168503154]
You guys make me want to open up my java book and read it straight through.The way you speak about it amazes me.

There isn’t an exception being thrown for using an item on an NPC. What is happening is this:

1: The server reads the byte for the user using an item on an NPC.
2: The server discards the next 4 bytes, knowing that they are part of the information that the client sends
3: The client sends more than 4 bytes, but the server thinks that the next thing it reads is a whole new cycle
4: The server reads a byte that is part of the current cycle, and thinks that the user is trying to attack a player
5: The server reads the next byte as the playerID of the player the user is trying to attack
6: Since the next byte is probably larger than the number of players on, the server crashes with an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when it tries to do step 5
[/quote]wow u are a big nerd lol

Immaturity at its best.

I reckon eh. The rules need to change - Firstly, in the part that they type ‘yes’, the rules need to state that you are to read AND follow specific forum section rules. Secondly, the rules need to state that failure to comply with those rules will result in an instant 2 day ban. Now that is what would clean this place up.[/quote]

Your sig also shows what this place is full of.Well at least that guy was able to admit it,Usually admitting is always the hardest part :).

Read full topic

item.description:

lothy:

Hmm, I’m just going to leave it how I had it after someone mentioned it in another post - It will just hand out an IP ban, and that will be that.

Or, you could put this in yout packetProcess switch:

default: disconnected  = true;

item.title: Aftermath's help thread
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

There isn’t an exception being thrown for using an item on an NPC. What is happening is this:

1: The server reads the byte for the user using an item on an NPC.
2: The server discards the next 4 bytes, knowing that they are part of the information that the client sends
3: The client sends more than 4 bytes, but the server thinks that the next thing it reads is a whole new cycle
4: The server reads a byte that is part of the current cycle, and thinks that the user is trying to attack a player
5: The server reads the next byte as the playerID of the player the user is trying to attack
6: Since the next byte is probably larger than the number of players on, the server crashes with an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when it tries to do step 5

Read full topic

item.title: Aftermath's help thread
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:3, topic:46399”][quote author=lothy link=topic=64594.msg758781#msg758781 date=1168498355]
Aww, how nice. What handles items being used on NPCs, besides what’s in case 57 which is found in the parseIncomingPackets void? I’ve already put a try catch there, and it still throws an exception, so something elsewhere is throwing the exception.
[/quote]

Heh, you know the server can’t just discard bytes like that you know? Like, a 57 could mean that the user used an item on an NPC, or it could also be the index of the player they are trying to attack. Each byte of information has to be considered contextually.[/quote]
I know. But if the particular byte is for an item being used on an NPC, shouldn’t it still catch the exception in that particular case?

Read full topic

Heh, you know the server can’t just discard bytes like that you know? Like, a 57 could mean that the user used an item on an NPC, or it could also be the index of the player they are trying to attack. Each byte of information has to be considered contextually.
